title: I have mixed feelings about Gangplank and Miss. Fortune
body:
For the record, I loved the story. This has set a new standard for lore and I hope Riot improves. Having said that, a part of me misses the old Gangplank. While I'll never call him a good man, I never would have taken him as the type to murder an entire family, burn their workshop, and destroy the guns he wanted made purely out of spite. I think it's a bit out of character even for the new Gangplank. He seems like a brutally fair man.

As for Miss Fortune, I'm happy that she had her past concluded, which was also developed. However, I feel conflicted on her now darker, more brutal and manipulative personality. I feel bad for her, but can't help but judge her either. I can accept having a burning hatred for Gangplank, but I liked their "friendly" rivalry, especially when it was thought that he was the boy that saved her when they were younger. 

My biggest question however is the Harrowing Event. Is the part involving these two canon? I can't see her working together with the man that caused her so much pain.

replies.body:
I actually find the idea of them [having to work together](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Harrowing#Fist_Light_after_the_Harrowing) to (barely) fend off a Harrowing, quite interesting actually.  It happened before Miss Fortune revealed her out-and-out hatred for Gangplank, so while she might be seething inside at having to sail alongside him, it's certainly not an act that she hadn't had to put on before.

I imagine it playing out where she almost seemed flattered that the great and powerful Captain Gangplank would call her up to assist in his epic fight against the Shadow Isles incursion.  And Captain Gangplank would be playing it off like it was throwing the other captains a bone to even let them come along - as he's obviously too powerful to need 'help'.

In the end, they work together because otherwise Bilgewater would have been completely overrun, and neither of them want that.  The mental gymnastics that both had to go through to make that temporary alliance right in their heads would probably have kept several psychologists busy for years.

This brings up something interesting thought. With Gangplank dethroned and Bilgewater in chaos, what's gonna stop an eleventh Harrowing from running through the entirety of Bilgewater and the Blue Flame Isles? Last time it took Nautilus splitting the undead forces and a unified armada to barely do it, and even than there were major casualties and Smuggler's Cove was just straight up wrecked.

With the chaos that'll have engulfed Bilgewater now, I fear for when the next Harrowing rolls on by.
